Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Award: The Use of Material Culture to Trace Historic Change

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will investigate the colonial history of Panama through the study of ceramics. The research is inspired by postcolonial debates that introduced notions of agency and negotiation in the structuration of colonial experiences. Local processes of colonial negotiations have been overshadowed by the splendor of the American, Asian, and European riches circulating through this region during the expansion of the imperial enterprise. As a result, non-European people still lack historical agency in the archaeological narratives of colonial Panama. Previous archaeological research highlights the disappearance of indigenous ceramic styles from the archaeological record and their replacement by European and creole styles. This evidence is used to affirm the extinction or assimilation of indigenous groups located in the areas the Spaniards occupied. However, in light of postcolonial debates, the previous statement raises questions about the process of technological change and the role of political and economic variables in colonial Panama. Did local communities keep control of some aspects of ceramic production? Did the Spanish appropriate local knowledge and resources in the production of ceramic technologies? The study of technology is a window to understand the impacts of colonization not accessible through documentary sources. This research will supplement and diversify the elite perspective of Spanish history and its narratives to include the participation of local and non-European communities in the construction of colonial Panama.

Based on a combination of historical, archaeological, and archaeometric research, MS. Navas will study indigenous production and consumption of ceramics under the supervision of Dr. Rodríguez-Alegría, as part of her doctoral dissertation research at the University of Texas. She will focus on the possible continuity, transformation or disruption of ceramic production and consumption after European colonization. The researcher aims to identify raw materials and technologies used in the production of ceramics in the pre-Columbian and colonial periods. Her study will be centered on compositional analyses of pastes, slips, and glazes of ceramic samples collected in previous excavations from three different Spanish colonial settlements: Nata de los Caballeros, Old Panama (Panama Viejo), and the Panama Historic District (Casco Antiguo). The inclusion of samples from these three sites will allow a regional comparative study of technological and compositional changes in ceramics from different production centers over the long term, starting in the Late Ceramic period (700 AD to conquest) to the nineteenth century. The analyses of the samples will be based on neutron activation analysis (NAA), petrographic thin section analysis, and laser ablation-inductively coupled plasma-mass spectrometry (LA-ICP-MS). These techniques will permit the identification of the constituent raw materials and techniques used in the production of ceramics and patterns of continuity or change in their use during the colonial period.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project examines the early colonial history of Panama through the study of production and consumption of ceramics. Previous archaeological research in Panama highlights the disappearance of indigenous ceramic styles and their replacement by European and creole styles after the Spanish Conquest. This evidence is used to affirm narratives of indigenous extinction or assimilation in areas the Spaniards occupied. Contrary to this approach, I show the continuity of indigenous technological traditions and their participation in the construction of colonial Panama, by identifying the raw materials and technologies used in ceramic production during the pre-Columbian and colonial periods in Panama. This allows the study of the transformation, emergence, and configuration of communities of potters after European colonization.

My study focuses on compositional and technological analyses of the ceramic body (pastes) and surfaces of 250 samples from the pre-Columbian and colonial periods (AD 700-1800) collected at indigenous and Spanish colonial settlements in Panama: Nata de los Caballeros, Old Panama, Panama Historic District, and sites identified in Coclé, Herrera, and Veraguas provinces. From 2017 to 2019 I conducted documentary research, sampled the potsherds from different storages in Panama, and analyzed the ceramic samples. The analyses included neutron activation analysis (NAA), laser ablation inductively coupled plasma-mass spectrometry (LA-ICPMS), and petrographic thin section analysis. These methods provided information about the chemical composition of pottery, understood as recipes used in the production of ceramics, and manufacturing technologies during the pre-Columbian and colonial periods.

My work has generated significant insights into the contribution of indigenous people in pottery production through the continuity of native recipes during the colonial period. The statistical analyses of NAA results allowed the identification of three compositional groups from the pre-Columbian period and the production of a new recipe in the colonial period. Pottery composition is the product of raw material procurement, manufacturing decisions, use, and post-depositional factors. At the same time, petrographic analysis revealed the use of a diverse array of tempers to produce the ceramics. The results show that, although Panama has a very heterogenous geological resources, people relied on the use of the same clay sources over time, continued using some tempers and in some cases incorporated new raw materials to produce ceramic recipes. Also, results show that while pre-Columbian recipes persisted for a long time during the colonial period new recipes appeared to produce European tableware introduced to the area. In general, the compositional and technological analyses performed allowed to generate new inferences about the organization of production before the Conquest and the emergence of new communities of potters in the processes of negotiation and transformation during colonization of Panama.

The findings from this research have strong implications for the revision of colonial Panamanian history. Historical narratives about indigenous people in Latin America affect contemporaneous notions of indigeneity and, very often, lead to the exclusion of these groups from processes of nation-building. Based on the importance of these representations, my research contributes to the creation of new versions of history that challenge the elite narratives of unavoidable extinction and passive assimilation of non-European groups. The analysis of technologies used before and after European colonization allows to give agency to marginalized groups. Furthermore, my research contributes to diversify the historical narratives and close the gap between precolonial and colonial archaeologies where indigenous histories get lost.
